column1: The hypothesis of mental continuity throughout organic evolution may be used in two different ways. On the one hand
column2: it may be held that we have more knowledge of our own minds than those of animals
column3: and that we should use this knowledge to infer the existence of something similar to our own mental processes in animals and even in plants. On the other hand
column4: it may be held that animals and plants present simpler phenomena
column5: more easily analyzed than those of human minds; on this ground it may be urged that explanations which are adequate in the case of animals ought not to be lightly rejected in the case of man. The practical effects of these two views are diametrically opposite: the first leads us to level up animal intelligence with what we believe ourselves to know about our own intelligence
column6: while the second leads us to attempt a levelling down of our own intelligence to something not too remote from what we can observe in animals. It is therefore important to consider the relative justification of the two ways of applying the principle of continuity.
